research_problem.title: Kissing Number in Dimension 5
research_problem.statement: Determine the exact kissing number tau_5, the maximum number of non-overlapping unit spheres in R^5 that can simultaneously touch a central unit sphere. Currently known: 40 <= tau_5 <= 44.
research_problem.verification: A single integer in {40,41,42,43,44}. Verified in Python by constructing N unit vectors in R^5 and checking all pairwise inner products satisfy |<v_i, v_j>| <= 0.5 (angular separation >= 60 degrees).
research_problem.methodology: Dimensional analysis on calculus: use the derivative/integral dimensional framework (d/dR[V_n] = S_{n-1}, V_n = integral of S_{n-1} dR, V_n = (2*pi/n)*R^2*V_{n-2}) to analyze spherical cap packing on S^4, computing cap solid angles via dimensional integration of S^3 cross-sections.

items.description: Analyze repository structure and set up computational environment
items.acceptance_criteria: Document listing all modules/directories and their purposes. Python environment verified with numpy, scipy, and itertools available. A file `repo_analysis.md` created in results/ describing the project layout and computational toolchain.
items.notes: Created results/repo_analysis.md with full project structure. Verified numpy 2.2.6, scipy 1.15.3, mpmath 1.3.0, cvxpy 1.7.5, networkx 3.4.2 all available. Created src/, tests/, results/, figures/ directories.

items.description: Conduct literature review on kissing number problem via web search
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search performed for 'kissing number dimension 5', 'spherical codes bounds', 'Delsarte linear programming bound', 'Levenshtein bound', 'Odlyzko Sloane kissing numbers'. At least 10 relevant papers identified covering: (a) Delsarte LP method, (b) semidefinite programming bounds, (c) D5 lattice constructions, (d) Pfender-Zong survey, (e) Musin's work on dimensions 3-4, (f) Cohn-Kumar universal optimality, (g) Boyvalenkov-Danev-Bumova improvements. Results summarized in results/literature_review.md.
items.notes: 13 papers identified covering all required topics. Literature review saved to results/literature_review.md with bounds history table, gap analysis, and opportunities for dimensional analysis approach.

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted sources
items.acceptance_criteria: File sources.bib exists in repo root with valid BibTeX entries for at least 10 papers including: Delsarte (1973), Kabatyansky-Levenshtein (1978), Odlyzko-Sloane (1979), Conway-Sloane 'Sphere Packings' book, Pfender-Zong (2004) survey, Musin (2008) on tau_4=24, Cohn-Kumar (2007) universal optimality, Mittelmann-Vallentin (2010) SDP bounds, Bachoc-Vallentin (2008), and Viazovska (2017) on dimension 8. Each entry has author, title, journal/booktitle, year, and DOI/URL where available.
items.notes: sources.bib created with 20 BibTeX entries covering all required papers plus Szollosi (2023), Cohn-Rajagopal (2024), Pfender (2007), Machado-Oliveira (2018), Cohn-Elkies (2003), and Schutte-van der Waerden (1953).

items.description: Formalize the dimensional analysis on calculus framework mathematically
items.acceptance_criteria: Document results/dimensional_framework.md created containing: (1) Proof that d/dR[V_n(R)] = S_{n-1}(R), (2) the recurrence V_n = (2*pi/n)*R^2*V_{n-2}, (3) spherical cap area formula A_cap(n,theta) derived via dimensional integration of S^{n-2} cross-sections, (4) the simple cap-packing upper bound tau_n <= S_{n-1}/A_cap(n,pi/6), (5) explicit computation for n=5 showing this gives an upper bound. All formulas verified symbolically or numerically in Python.
items.notes: Created results/dimensional_framework.md with proofs, recurrence verification, cap area derivation, and n=5 computation. Cap bound gives tau_5 <= 77 (weaker than Delsarte's 44 but provides geometric insight). All formulas verified numerically.

items.description: Study the D5 lattice and its kissing configuration achieving tau_5 >= 40
items.acceptance_criteria: Python script src/d5_lattice.py created that: (1) generates all 40 minimal vectors of the D5 lattice, (2) verifies they are unit vectors (after normalization), (3) computes all 780 pairwise inner products and confirms |<v_i,v_j>| <= 0.5 for i != j, (4) prints the contact graph structure (which pairs achieve equality |<v_i,v_j>| = 0.5). Script runs successfully and outputs are saved to results/d5_verification.txt.
items.notes: D5 lattice verified: 40 vectors, all pairwise inner products <= 0.5, contact graph is 12-regular with 240 contact pairs. Inner product spectrum: {-1, -0.5, 0, +0.5}. Configuration is VALID.

items.description: Survey existing upper bound techniques and identify gaps for dimensional analysis approach
items.acceptance_criteria: Document results/upper_bound_survey.md summarizing: (1) Delsarte LP bound for n=5 (gives tau_5 <= 44), (2) SDP/3-point bound improvements, (3) why the gap 40-44 persists, (4) identification of at least 2 specific places where dimensional integration arguments could tighten bounds (e.g., constraining Gegenbauer coefficients via volume/surface-area identities, or ruling out specific contact graph structures via cap-packing geometry). Cites at least 5 papers from sources.bib.
items.notes: Created upper_bound_survey.md. Identified 3 opportunities: (1) constraining Gegenbauer coefficients via volume identities, (2) ruling out contact graph structures via dimensional volume, (3) cross-dimensional density constraints. Cites 9 papers.

items.description: Implement n-dimensional ball volume and surface area functions with dimensional recurrence
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module src/ndim_geometry.py implementing: V_n(R), S_{n-1}(R), cap_area(n, theta), cap_solid_angle(n, theta) using both the Gamma function formula and the 2-step recurrence V_n = (2*pi/n)*R^2*V_{n-2}. Unit tests in tests/test_ndim_geometry.py verify: (a) V_3(1) = 4*pi/3, (b) V_5(1) = 8*pi^2/15, (c) S_4(1) = 8*pi^2/3, (d) recurrence matches Gamma formula to 1e-12 for n=1..20, (e) cap_area(3, pi/6) matches known value. All tests pass.
items.notes: All 7 tests pass: V_3, V_5, S_4 exact values, recurrence matches Gamma to 1e-12 for n=1..20, cap_area(3,pi/6) matches, derivative relationship verified, hemisphere cap fraction = 0.5.

items.description: Implement Delsarte linear programming bound computation for kissing numbers
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module src/delsarte_lp.py that: (1) computes Gegenbauer polynomials C_k^{lambda}(t) for lambda=(n-2)/2, (2) sets up the Delsarte LP: maximize f(1) subject to f_hat(k) >= 0 and f(t) <= 0 for t in [-1, 0.5], (3) solves via scipy.optimize.linprog or cvxpy, (4) reproduces the known bound tau_5 <= 44 (within floating point tolerance). Output saved to results/delsarte_baseline.txt showing the bound and the optimal polynomial coefficients.
items.notes: Implemented Delsarte LP using polynomial ansatz search. Verified known n=8 polynomial gives exactly tau_8=240. For n=5, our search gives tau_5<=51 (not optimal LP of 46). The optimal LP bound of 44 (from SDP) is documented. Semi-infinite LP discretization is inherently unbounded; used Levenshtein polynomial approach instead.

items.description: Implement spherical code validator and optimizer
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module src/spherical_codes.py with functions: (1) validate_kissing_config(vectors) that checks all vectors are unit and all pairwise angles >= 60 degrees, returns True/False and reports violations, (2) greedy_spherical_code(n, target_k) that attempts to place target_k points on S^{n-1} with minimum angle >= 60 degrees using random initialization + gradient-based local optimization, (3) the validator correctly accepts the 40-point D5 configuration and rejects random 45-point configurations. Tests in tests/test_spherical_codes.py pass.
items.notes: All 4 tests pass. D5 accepted (40 valid vectors), random 45-point rejected (149 violations), greedy places 6/6 in R^3 and only 21/50 in R^5.

items.description: Establish baseline metrics and benchmarks table
items.acceptance_criteria: File results/baseline_metrics.md containing a table with columns [Dimension, Known_Lower, Known_Upper, Cap_Packing_Bound, Delsarte_LP_Bound, Our_Recurrence_Bound] for dimensions 2-8. All known values cited from sources.bib. The cap-packing bound (simple area ratio) and Delsarte LP bound are computed by our code for each dimension. Comparison shows where dimensional analysis adds information beyond Delsarte LP alone.
items.notes: Table shows cap-packing bound is exponentially weaker than Delsarte LP. For n=5: cap=77, LP=46, SDP=44. Key observation: dimensional analysis provides geometric insight but simple cap bound doesn't improve on LP.

items.description: Derive dimensional integration constraints on Gegenbauer coefficients
items.acceptance_criteria: Mathematical derivation (in results/dimensional_constraints.md) showing how the n-ball volume recurrence V_n = (2*pi/n)*V_{n-2} imposes constraints on the Gegenbauer polynomial expansion of feasible angular distributions on S^4. Specifically: (1) derive that the total solid angle of k caps of angular radius pi/6 on S^4 must equal k * A_cap(5, pi/6) <= S_4, giving the trivial cap bound, (2) derive at least one non-trivial constraint from the fact that the dimensional recurrence links S^4 cap areas to S^3 and S^2 cap areas via integration, (3) show how these constraints can be added to the Delsarte LP. All formulas verified numerically.
items.notes: Created results/dimensional_constraints.md with 6 sections: trivial cap bound (tau_5<=77), cross-dimensional integration identity (cap area verified via betainc and numerical integration), equatorial slicing constraint (degree bound from tau_4=24), second-moment trace constraint (consistent for all k<=77), and volume recurrence as LP constraint (Gegenbauer coefficient cross-dimensional recurrence).

items.description: Implement enhanced LP/SDP with dimensional analysis constraints
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module src/enhanced_bound.py that extends the Delsarte LP from item_008 by adding the dimensional integration constraints from item_011. The enhanced bound is computed for n=5. If the bound improves below 44 (e.g., tau_5 <= 43 or 42), this is a novel result. Output results/enhanced_bound_results.txt with: (a) the new upper bound value, (b) comparison with Delsarte's 44, (c) the additional constraints used, (d) sensitivity analysis showing which constraints are active.
items.notes: Enhanced bound with D1 (equatorial slicing), D2 (trace), D3 (volume recurrence) constraints does NOT improve below Delsarte LP. Our ansatz gives tau_5<=51, literature optimal LP is 44. All dimensional constraints are redundant: D1 (degree<=24) too loose, D2 vacuous for n>=4, D3 is a soft geometric constraint that doesn't restrict LP certificate space. Detailed redundancy analysis in enhanced_bound_results.txt.

items.description: Investigate dimensional pyramid decomposition of spherical caps
items.acceptance_criteria: Analysis in results/pyramid_decomposition.md exploring the insight that integral(x^2) = x^3/3 corresponds to a pyramid being 1/3 of a cube. Apply this to S^4: (1) decompose the spherical cap on S^4 into infinitesimal 'pyramids' from the pole, each contributing dV = (1/5)*r^4*dOmega, (2) derive how the 1/n factor in V_n = S_{n-1}*R/n constrains the packing of caps on S^{n-1}, (3) explore whether the 1/5 factor for n=5 creates tighter geometric constraints than in other dimensions (since 1/5 is smaller than 1/3 or 1/4, each cap 'wastes' more volume in higher dimensions). Include at least 3 numerically verified lemmas.
items.notes: Thorough analysis in pyramid_decomposition.md with 3 verified lemmas: (1) V_n/S_{n-1}=1/n decreasing with n, (2) cap density rho_n<=1 with equality iff n=2, (3) pyramid volume bound gives same tau_5<=77 as cap bound. Key result: 1/n factor cancels because both cone volume and total ball volume scale with 1/n. Cap density for tau_5=40 is 51.4%, for tau_5=44 is 56.6%.

items.description: Attempt construction of 41-point or 42-point kissing configurations in R^5
items.acceptance_criteria: Python script src/construct_kissing.py that: (1) starts from the 40-point D5 configuration, (2) uses at least 3 strategies to attempt adding a 41st point: (a) exhaustive search over a grid on S^4, (b) nonlinear optimization (minimize max violation of angular constraint), (c) algebraic construction based on symmetry subgroups of D5, (3) if a 41-point configuration is found, it is validated by the validator from item_009 and saved to results/kissing_41.npy. If no 41-point configuration is found, results/construction_attempts.md documents all strategies tried and why they failed, providing evidence toward tau_5 = 40.
items.notes: No 41st point found. Three strategies attempted: (1) grid search 100K samples - 0 valid, (2) nonlinear optimization 50 starts - best max IP 0.632456, margin -0.132, (3) algebraic construction 354 candidates - 0 valid. Best approach still 0.132 away from feasibility. Results in construction_attempts.md.

items.description: Analyze the contact graph structure using dimensional volume arguments
items.acceptance_criteria: Analysis in results/contact_graph_analysis.md that: (1) enumerates the possible contact graph structures for hypothetical 41-44 point kissing configurations in R^5, using the constraint that each vertex has degree related to the kissing number in R^4 (tau_4 = 24), (2) uses dimensional volume arguments to show certain contact graph structures are impossible (e.g., if a graph requires too many caps in a specific sub-arrangement, the dimensional volume bound from the recurrence rules it out), (3) if possible, eliminates tau_5 = 44 or tau_5 = 43 using these arguments. All graph-theoretic claims verified computationally.
items.notes: Comprehensive analysis in contact_graph_analysis.md. D5 graph: 40 vertices, 12-regular, 240 edges, omega=4, alpha=8, chi=5, vertex-transitive 4-class association scheme. REFINED degree bound: d(v)<=21 (not 24) because projected neighbors on S^3 have min angle arccos(1/3)=70.53°. D5 is locally rigid: min max IP = sqrt(2/5)=0.6325 > 0.5 (gap 9.23°). Graph-theoretic constraints cannot rule out k=41-44; the obstruction is geometric, not combinatorial.

items.description: Cross-dimensional consistency check using V_n recurrence
items.acceptance_criteria: Python script src/cross_dim_check.py that exploits the recurrence V_n = (2*pi/n)*V_{n-2} to derive constraints across dimensions. Specifically: (1) if tau_5 = K, compute what this implies about the maximum density of spherical caps on S^4, (2) project this density to S^3 and S^2 using the dimensional recurrence and check consistency with known tau_3 = 12 and tau_4 = 24, (3) report which values of K in {40,...,44} are consistent with the cross-dimensional constraints. Output to results/cross_dim_results.txt.
items.notes: All values {40,...,44} pass the simple cross-dimensional consistency check. Cap coverage ranges 51.4%-56.6%, all below 100%. The omega ratio omega_5/omega_3 does not equal 2*pi/5 (because caps are not balls), so the volume recurrence does not directly eliminate candidates. Contact graph degree constraint (<=24) is also easily satisfied.

items.description: Run comprehensive numerical experiments for all approaches
items.acceptance_criteria: Script src/run_experiments.py that executes all computational approaches from Phase 3 with multiple parameter settings. Produces results/experiments_summary.csv with columns [Method, Dimension, Parameters, Upper_Bound, Lower_Bound, Runtime_Seconds, Notes]. At least 50 distinct experiment configurations run. All results reproducible with fixed random seeds.
items.notes: Created src/run_experiments.py running 119 experiment configurations across 7 categories: cap packing (n=2..8), Delsarte LP (n=3,5), D5 verification, greedy spherical codes (multiple n and targets), construction attempts (reduced scale), cross-dimensional checks, and cap area sweep. CSV output with proper columns. All experiments use fixed seeds.

items.description: Verify all results independently using multiple numerical methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Script src/verify_results.py that cross-checks every claimed bound using at least 2 independent methods. For any upper bound improvement: (a) verify the LP/SDP is feasible and the dual certificate is valid, (b) verify using interval arithmetic (mpmath with sufficient precision) that rounding errors don't invalidate the bound. For any new construction: (a) verify with exact rational arithmetic if possible, (b) verify pairwise distances to at least 50 decimal places using mpmath. All verifications pass and are logged to results/verification_log.txt.
items.notes: Created src/verify_results.py with 8 verification categories: ball volumes (Gamma vs recurrence, mpmath 50-digit), surface areas (formula vs derivative), cap areas (betainc vs numerical integration), D5 lattice (unit norms, pairwise IPs), cap packing bound (area vs volume), Delsarte n=8 polynomial (scipy vs mpmath), contact graph (12-regular, 240 edges), local rigidity (sqrt(2/5)). All verifications logged to verification_log.txt.

items.description: Compare results against all prior work from literature review
items.acceptance_criteria: Document results/comparison_with_prior_work.md containing: (1) table comparing our bounds with every paper in sources.bib that gives a bound on tau_5, (2) identification of exactly what is novel in our approach vs. prior work, (3) if our bound matches a prior result, explanation of whether our derivation is genuinely different, (4) if our bound improves on prior work, precise statement of the improvement with proof sketch. At least 8 papers from sources.bib explicitly compared.
items.notes: Created comparison_with_prior_work.md with 10 papers compared in table, identification of 5 novel aspects (dimensional framework, enhanced LP, refined degree bound 21, local rigidity proof, pyramid decomposition), honest assessment that no bound improvement was achieved, and analysis of framework limitations. 276 lines.

items.description: Generate visualizations of key results
items.acceptance_criteria: Python script src/generate_figures.py producing at least 4 figures saved as PNG in figures/: (1) figures/cap_packing_s4.png - visualization of spherical cap packing constraints on S^4 (projected to 2D/3D), (2) figures/bound_comparison.png - bar chart comparing upper bounds from different methods across dimensions 2-8, (3) figures/dimensional_recurrence.png - plot of V_n, S_n, and cap ratios showing the dimensional recurrence relationships, (4) figures/contact_graph.png - graph visualization of the D5 kissing configuration's contact structure. All figures have proper labels, titles, and legends.
items.notes: Created src/generate_figures.py producing 4 PNG figures: bound_comparison.png (grouped bars for 4 methods across dims 2-8), dimensional_recurrence.png (4-panel: V_n, S_n, V/S=1/n, cap fractions), cap_density.png (density vs n with tau_5=40 and 44 markers), contact_graph.png (40-node D5 graph with spring layout). All dpi=150 with labels/legends.

items.description: Sensitivity analysis on dimensional constraints
items.acceptance_criteria: Results file results/sensitivity_analysis.md documenting: (1) how each dimensional constraint from item_011 individually affects the LP bound, (2) which constraints are most impactful (ranked by bound improvement), (3) robustness of bounds to numerical precision (tested at 16, 32, 64, and 128-bit precision), (4) whether the dimensional constraints become more or less effective as dimension increases (tested for n=3..8). All data backed by computational evidence in results/sensitivity_data.csv.
items.notes: Created results/sensitivity_analysis.md with 5 sections: (1) individual constraint impact showing D1/D2/D3 all non-binding for n=5 with zero impact, (2) constraint rankings (D2 > D1 > D3 by potential utility, but none impactful for n=5), (3) numerical precision robustness tested at dps=16/32/64/128 showing 15+ digit agreement across all precisions, (4) dimensional scaling for n=3..8 showing D2 useful only for n<=3, D1 never binding, D3 never binding. Created results/sensitivity_data.csv with 24 rows covering 6 dimensions x 4 precision levels.

items.description: Write main research report
items.acceptance_criteria: File results/research_report.md (at least 2000 words) containing: (1) Abstract summarizing the problem, approach, and main results, (2) Introduction with motivation and connection to dimensional analysis on calculus, (3) Methods section describing the Delsarte LP, dimensional constraints, construction attempts, and contact graph analysis, (4) Results section with all numerical findings, (5) Discussion comparing to prior work with explicit citations from sources.bib, (6) Conclusion stating the best bounds achieved and open questions. Report is well-structured with section headings, numbered equations, and figure references.
items.notes: Research report at 4783 words with Abstract, Introduction, Background, Dimensional Analysis Framework, Methods, Results (5 subsections), Discussion, Conclusion, and References. Includes figure references, numbered equations, citations from sources.bib. Covers all findings honestly: no new bound achieved, but dimensional framework provides geometric insights.

items.description: Document the dimensional analysis on calculus framework as a standalone contribution
items.acceptance_criteria: File results/dimensional_analysis_framework.md documenting the general framework independent of the kissing number application: (1) formal statement of the derivative/integral dimensional correspondence, (2) the n-ball recurrence as the fundamental identity, (3) at least 3 worked examples beyond kissing numbers where this framework yields geometric insights (e.g., sphere volume maximization at n=5, Isoperimetric inequality, pyramid volume formula), (4) discussion of limitations and when the framework does vs. doesn't provide useful constraints. At least 1500 words.
items.notes: Framework document at 3265 words with 5 sections: formal statement (derivative/integral correspondence), n-ball recurrence (proof and interpretation), 3+ worked examples (volume peak at n~5.26, isoperimetric inequality, pyramid volume formula), limitations analysis (single-body vs multi-body), and connections to broader mathematics (Gamma function, Beta function, Gegenbauer polynomials, SO(n) representation theory).

items.description: Create reproducibility package
items.acceptance_criteria: File requirements.txt listing all Python dependencies with pinned versions. File README.md updated with: (1) project description, (2) installation instructions, (3) how to reproduce all results (single command `python src/run_experiments.py`), (4) description of output files. Running `pip install -r requirements.txt && python src/run_experiments.py` from a clean environment produces all results files and figures without error.
items.notes: Created requirements.txt with pinned versions: numpy==2.2.6, scipy==1.15.3, mpmath==1.3.0, matplotlib==3.10.8, networkx==3.4.2. Updated README.md with project title, description, installation instructions, reproduction commands (run_experiments.py, verify_results.py, generate_figures.py), tables describing all 18 results/ files, 4 figures/ files, and 10 src/ files, plus citation information pointing to sources.bib. Verified with pip install --dry-run.

items.description: Final review and self-assessment
items.acceptance_criteria: File results/self_assessment.md containing: (1) honest assessment of whether any new bound on tau_5 was achieved (if not, explain what was learned), (2) ranking of the most promising approaches tried, (3) specific suggestions for future work that could close the gap, (4) assessment of the dimensional analysis framework's utility (did it genuinely help, or was it more of a reformulation?), (5) list of all files produced with one-line descriptions. All items in research_rubric.json updated to final status (completed/failed with notes).
items.notes: Self-assessment with 5 sections: (1) No new bound achieved - honest analysis of why, (2) 6 approaches ranked (contact graph refined degree bound most promising), (3) 7 future work suggestions, (4) Framework assessment: useful for pedagogy and geometric intuition but does not compete with spectral methods, (5) complete file inventory with 30+ files described.
